questions.text: The foetal blood is separated from syncytiotropho- blast with all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The maternal blood in the lacuna is never in direct contact with fetal blood. They are separated by:

  • Syncytiotrophoblast
  • Cytotrophoblast(Option B ruled out)
  • Basement membrane Together called as placental barrier or membrane (0.025 mm)
  • Mesoderm
  • Endothelium of fetal capillaries

questions.text: The uterine blood flow at term?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Uterine blood flow in nonpregnant females = 50 ml/min
  • Uterine blood flow in pregnant females = 750 ml/min

choices.text: An indicator of considerably increased incidence of major malformation of the fetus
Equally common in newborn of diabetic and nondiabetic mothers

questions.text: The finding of a single umbilical artery on examination of the umbilical cord after delivery is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Single Umbilical Artery

  • It is seen in 0.7-0.8% cases of single pregnancy and 5% of twin pregnancy
  • More common in diabetic patients, black patients, with eclampsia, hydramnios and oligohydramnios, epilepsy patients and in APH.(Option A, B and D ruled out)
  • Finding of a single umbilical artery is not insignificant and is associated with
    • Congenital malformations of the fetus in 20-25% cases amongst which cardiovascular and genitourinary anomalies are common.
    • Increased chances of abortion, prematurity, IUGR and perinatal mortality.

questions.text: All are true regarding Mathew Duncan's placental separation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Placental Separation:

There are 2 Mechanism of placental separation

  • Central separation: Schultz mechanism
  • Peripheral: Mathew Duncan mechanism.
  • 1. Schultze Mechanism (Most Common):
  • Process:
    • Retroplacental hematoma forms → pushes center of placenta forward → separation starts from center.
    • Placenta descends, dragging membranes and peeling them from the uterine wall.
    • Glistening amnion (fetal surface) presents at the vulva.
  • Blood Flow:
    • Blood collects behind the placenta in the membrane sac.
    • External bleeding occurs only after placental expulsion.
  • Placental Surface Seen First: Fetal surface (amnion).
  • 2. Duncan Mechanism:
  • Process:
    • Placenta separates from the periphery first.
    • Blood collects between membranes and uterine wall → escapes externally before the placenta is expelled.
    • Placenta descends sideways.
    • Maternal surface presents first.
  • Blood Flow:
    • External bleeding occurs early.
  • Placental Surface Seen First: Maternal surface.

Key Takeaways:

  • Schultze = Central separation → Fetal surface first → Late bleeding.
  • Duncan = Marginal separation → Maternal surface first → Early bleeding.

questions.text: Fertilised ovum reaches uterine cavity by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As fertilisation of the ovum occurs and a zygote is formed, it undergoes cleavage to form 3, 4, 6 cell stage.This cleavage continues till it is 16 cell staged and is called as Morula.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • Some fluid passes from the uterine cavity into the morula. So that the inner cell mass attaches to the trophoblast on one side only. The morula now becomes a 'blastocyst'.
  • As the blastocyst develops further the inner cell mass differentiates into ectoderm and endoderm initially followed by mesoderm later.
    • From the time a fertilized ovum enters the uterine cavity from the fallopian tube (which occurs 3-4 days after ovulation) until the time ovum implants (7-9 days after ovulation) the uterine secretions called uterine milk provides nutrition for the early dividing ovum.
    • At the time of implantation, on days 21-22 of the menstrual cycle the predominant morphologic feature is edema of the endometrial stroma.
  • Zygote enters the uterine cavity in the form of Morula
  • Zygote enters the uterine cavity - On 17-18th day of menstrual cycle, i.e 3-4 days after the fertilisation.
  • Implantation of the zygote occurs in the form of- Blastocyst
  • Implantation occurs on-6-8 days after fertilisation, i.e 20-22nd day of menstrual cycle.
  • Implantation is completed 10-11 days after fertilization

questions.text: Amniotic fluid is mainly produced by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The precise origin of the amniotic fluid remains is still not well understood. It is probably of mixed maternal and fetal origin.
  • In early pregnancy, amniotic fluid is an ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma. By the beginning of the second trimester, it consists largely of extracellular fluid which diffuses through the fetal skin, and thus reflects the composition of fetal plasma.
  • After 20 weeks, however, the cornification of fetal skin prevents this diffusion and amniotic fluid is composed largely of fetal urine.

questions.text: After how many days of ovulation embryo implantation occurs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fertilisation: Occurs within 24 hours of ovulation, forming the zygote.
  • Cleavage: Zygote undergoes cleavage into 3, 4, 6 cell stages.
  • Morula: By the 16-cell stage, it is called a morula.
  • Entry into uterine cavity: The zygote enters the uterine cavity in the form of a morula 3-4 days after fertilisation (on day 17-18 of the menstrual cycle).
  • Blastocyst formation: Some fluid enters the morula, forming the blastocyst, with inner cell mass attaching to one side of the trophoblast.
  • Implantation form: Implantation occurs in the blastocyst stage.
  • Timing of implantation: Begins 6-8 days after fertilisation (around day 20-22 of the menstrual cycle).(Option A,C and D is ruled out)
  • Completion of implantation: By 10-11 days after fertilisation.

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is/are associated with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Causes of Oligohydramnios

  1. Fetal Renal Abnormalities (↓ Urine Production)
    • Bilateral renal agenesis(Option B ruled out)
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (infantile form)
  2. Fetal Lower Urinary Tract Obstruction
    • Bladder outlet obstruction
    • Persistent cloaca
    • Sirenomelia
  3. Drug Exposure (Affects Renal Perfusion or Urine Production)
    • ACE inhibitors (especially in 2nd or 3rd trimester)
    • Angiotensin receptor blockers
    • NSAIDs (may cause ductus arteriosus constriction & ↓ urine output)
  4. Uteroplacental Insufficiency (↓ Perfusion)
    • Placental abnormalities
    • Maternal complications like:
      • Preeclampsia
      • Chronic hypertension
      • Other vascular diseases
  5. Ruptured Membranes
    • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM)
  6. Chronic Abruption-Oligohydramnios Sequence (CAOS)
    • Severe placental hematoma or chronic abruption
    • Often associated with fetal growth restriction
  7. Post term pregnancy (Option C ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

  • Neural tube defects(Option A):In NTD like anencephaly, the absence of forebrain and cranial nerves leads to absent or poor swallowing, resulting in fluid accumulation.

questions.text: In which of the following transition meiosis occurs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The process involved in the development of spermatids from the primordial male germ cells and their differentiation into spermatozoa (or sperms) is called spermatogenesis.
  • Spermatogenesis begins at puberty in seminiferous tubules of male testes.
  • Cell divisions are of two kinds:
    • In mitosis, the chromosome number remains the same.
    • Meiosis is a special type of cell division that reduces the diploid number of chromosomes (i.e., 46) to the haploid number of 23. It takes place only in germ cells; to give rise to gametes (sperms and egg cells) It involves two meiotic cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.
  • The first mitotic division is a reduction division because the chromosome number is reduced from diploid (46) to haploid (23).
  • The 2nd meiotic division is similar to mitosis as daughter cells formed contain the same haploid number of chromosomes as the mother cell.
  • Spermatogonia → Primary spermatocyte occurs by mitosis (Option D ruled out)
  • Spermatids → Spermatozoa This is called spermiogenesis, involving morphological changes.(Option B ruled out)

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division
1st polar body is extruded during 1st meiotic division of primary oocytes
Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 2nd meiotic division

questions.text: True statement regarding oogenesis are all except ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The secondary oocyte arrests in the metaphase of the second meiotic division, not the first.

The process involved in the development of mature ovum is called Oogenesis.

Oogenesis Process:

  • Initiation of Oogenesis: Oogenesis is the process of forming female gametes, known as oocytes, from Primordial Germ Cells (PGCs). This process begins long before birth and takes place in the cortex of the ovary.
  • PGC Division: PGCs undergo mitotic division to produce a large number of cells called oogonia.
  • Formation of Primary Oocyte:Each oogonium enlarges to become a primary oocyte.
  • Prophase of 1st Meiotic Division: The primary oocyte enters the prophase of the first meiotic division before birth. However, this division is arrested until puberty due to the presence of an oocyte maturation inhibitor (OMI) factor secreted by the follicular cells surrounding the oocyte.
  • Completion of 1st Meiotic Division: The first meiotic division is completed only when primary oocytes start maturing and preparing for ovulation.
  • Puberty and Ovulation: At puberty, during each ovarian cycle, 5-50 primary oocytes resume their first meiotic division, which is completed just before ovulation. This division results in two daughter cells, one of which is a secondary oocyte, and the other is the first polar body.
  • Formation of Secondary Oocyte: The secondary oocyte enters the second meiotic division at the time of ovulation. However, this division is completed only after a sperm has penetrated the secondary oocyte. The second meiotic division is also unequal, resulting in one daughter cell receiving most of the cytoplasm and forming the ovum, while the other daughter cell receives a minimal amount of cytoplasm and forms the second polar body.
  • Final Outcome: From one primary oocyte, only one ovum with 22 autosomes and one X chromosome is formed, along with three polar bodies, each containing 22 autosomes and one X chromosome.
  • This process of oogenesis is crucial for the production of female gametes and is tightly regulated by hormonal and physiological factors throughout a woman's reproductive life.

Explanation of other options:

  • Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division(Option A): Primary oocytes arrest in the prophase of the first meiotic division and remain arrested until puberty.
  • The 1st polar body is extruded during 1st meiotic division of primary oocytes(Option B): During the first meiotic division of primary oocytes, the first polar body is extruded, along with a secondary oocyte.
  • Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 2nd meiotic division(Option D): The secondary oocyte does arrest in the metaphase of the second meiotic division until fertilization occurs.

questions.text: Figure shows T:S of uterus with implanted zygote identify structure A:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Implantation occurs 7 - 9 days after ovulationIn humans, the blastocyst burrows in the uterine cavity till the whole of it lies within the thickness of endometrium. This is called as interstitial implantation After implantation of the embryo the uterine endometrium is called the "decidua
    • Decidua basalis - The part of the decidua where the placenta is to be formed (A in the figure).
    • Decidua capsularis - The part of the decidua that separates the embryo from the uterine lumen.(Option B ruled out)
    • Decidua parietalis (vera) - The part of the decidua lining rest of the uterine cavity.(Option C ruled out)
  • At the end of pregnancy, the decidua is shed off along with placenta and membranes.

questions.text: Causes of polyhydramnios include all except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Renal agenesis causes oligohydramnios, not polyhydramnios, because absence of kidneys leads to failure of fetal urine production, which is the major contributor to amniotic fluid in the second half of pregnancy.
  • Polyhydramnios: Excessive amniotic fluid → caused by increased fetal urine output (e.g., diabetes) or impaired fetal swallowing (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia).

questions.text: Which part of the sperm is formed by the mitochondria during spermiogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During spermiogenesis, the mitochondria of the spermatid form the middle piece of the sperm.
  • The middle piece is a region of the sperm that contains mitochondria and other organelles that provide energy for sperm movement. The mitochondria are densely packed in the middle piece, which is why this region of the sperm appears darker in color.

Explanation of other options:

  • Acrosomal cap(Option A): The acrosomal cap is a cap-like structure that covers the anterior portion of the sperm nucleus. It is formed from the Golgi apparatus of the spermatid.
  • Axial filament(Option C): The axial filament is a flagellum-like structure that propels the sperm forward. It is formed from the centrioles of the spermatid.
  • Head of sperm(Option D): The head of the sperm contains the nucleus, which contains the sperm's genetic material.

questions.text: A case of 35-week pregnancy with polyhydramnios and marked respiratory distress is best treated by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient in the question has marked respiratory distress (i.e. it is a severe polyhydramnios and requires treatment) and gestational age is 35 weeks (i.e., fetal maturity is not yet achieved).So our aim should be to relieve the distress of patients in hope of continuing the pregnancy till at least 37 weeks.
  • This can be achieved by:(Option A,B and D ruled out)
    • Amniocentesis
    • Use of Indomethacin
  • Amniocentesis:
    • The main aim of amniocentesis is to relieve maternal distress with the added advantage that lung maturity of the fetus can be predicted by Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio in the expressed fluid.
    • Slow decompression is done at the rate of 500 ml/hr.
    • Maximum fluid removed is 1.5 - 2 litres.
  • Use of Indomethacin -Indomethacin should not be used for more than 32 weeks because it leads to premature closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Amniotomy: The main disadvantage of amniotomy is the possibility of cord prolapse and placental abruption. Slow removal fluid by amniocentesis helps to obviate these dangers.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation is admitted in early labor. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, but a routine third-trimester ultrasound had noted a velamentous cord insertion. Two hours into labor, following spontaneous rupture of membranes, she develops sudden painless vaginal bleeding. Fetal heart monitoring shows severe bradycardia.What is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vasa previa occurs when fetal blood vessels traverse the membranes over the cervical os, unprotected by Wharton's jelly.
  • These vessels are vulnerable to rupture during membrane rupture, leading to:
    • Painless vaginal bleeding (since it's fetal, not maternal blood)
    • Rapid fetal blood loss → fetal bradycardia or death
  • Velamentous cord insertion is a major risk factor for vasa previa.
  • The other options (B): Decidua basalis, (C): Battledore placenta, and (D): Succenturiate placenta, are not specifically associated with the risk of fetal blood loss in the context of abnormal cord insertion.
  • Normally, the umbilical cord is inserted at the centre of the fetal surface of the placenta.

Explanation of other options:

  • Decidua basalis(Option B): This is a maternal layer of the endometrium that forms part of the placenta. It is not a clinical condition, and not associated with acute bleeding or bradycardia in labor.
  • Battledore placenta(Option C): Refers to marginal insertion of the umbilical cord. Generally benign and not associated with vasa previa or fetal hemorrhage. Does not explain sudden bleeding with fetal bradycardia.
  • Succenturiate placenta(Option D): An accessory placental lobe. May cause retained placental tissue or bleeding after delivery, but not acute fetal distress during labor. Not typically associated with painless bleeding + bradycardia after ROM.

Key Takeaways:

  • Velamentous cord insertion → predisposes to vasa previa → rupture of membranes → tearing of fetal vessels → painless bleeding + fetal bradycardia.

questions.text: Placenta Succenturiata may have all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Placenta Succenturiata is associated with postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), missing lobe, and potential infection issues like sepsis and subinvolution. It typically doesn't have a direct association with preterm delivery(Option B, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Weight gain in pregnancy is related to all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Smoking does not affect maternal weight gain during pregnancy, Smoking affects fetal weight gain and is one of the causes of IUGR.
  • Average maternal weight gain during pregnancy is 11-12 kg

Factors which affect maternal weight gain during pregnancy are:

  • Pre pregnancy weight: If the pre pregnancy weight is more than normal (obese), there is a tendency to gain excessive weight during pregnancy.
  • Race and ethnicity: American women tend to put on more weight during pregnancy as compared to Asians and Africans.(Option A ruled out)
  • Socio economic status: Women from higher socio economic groups have more weight gain as compared to women from lower socio economic groups. This is because malnutrition prevents optimum weight gain.(Option C ruled out)
  • Associated conditions like women with gestational/over diabetes mellitus, twins and polyhydramnios have higher weight gain during pregnancy
  • Parity: Multigravida females tend to gain less weight than primigravida

choices.text: Shift of apical impulse laterally and upwards in left 4th intercostal space

questions.text: Which cardiovascular change is physiological in the last trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Clinical findings related to cardiovascular changes occurring during pregnancy:
    • Heart rate (resting) increases by about 10-15 bpm.
    • Apex beat shifts to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid clavicular line (as heart is pushed upwards, outward, with slight rotation to left). (Option A,B and D ruled out)
    • Slightly enlarged cardiac silhouette. (marked enlarged cardiac silhouette is not normal in pregnancy)
    • Exaggerated splitting of the first heart sound (both components loud).
    • Second heart sound: Normal
    • Third heart sound: Loud and easily auscultated.
  • Murmurs
    • Grade II systolic ejection murmur is audible in aortic or pulmonary area at about 10-12 weeks due to expanded intravenous volume. It disappears in the beginning of the postpartum period.(Option A ruled out)
    • Continuous hissing murmur audible over the tricuspid area in left 2nd and 3rd intercostal spaces known as Mammary murmur.
  • ECHO - Shows increased left atrial and ventricular diameters.
  • ECG - Shows left axis deviation.
  • Chest X-ray - Straightening of left heart border.

questions.text: All of the following changes are seen in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During normal pregnancy:
    • Stroke volume increases due to hypervolemia and increased end-diastolic volume (Option A ruled out)
    • Cardiac output increases by approximately 30-50%, reaching a plateau in mid- to late pregnancy (Option B ruled out)
    • Intravascular volume increases by about 40-50%, comprising both plasma and red cell mass (Option C ruled out)
    • However, peripheral vascular resistance decreases (due to systemic vasodilation), rather than increasing systolic and diastolic blood pressure typically decrease in early pregnancy and remain below nonpregnant levels until term
    • In pregnancy since the main hormone is progesterone, which has a smooth muscle relaxant effect so peripheral vascular resistance decreases during pregnancy and therefore there is a fall in BP during pregnancy.

choices.text: Increase in serum iron binding capacity
Increase in blood oxygen carrying capacity

questions.text: All of the following may be observed in a normal pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In normal pregnancy: Since plasma volume increases more in comparison to Red cell volume so viscosity of blood decreases (not increases) (option C ruled out)
  • Since total hemoglobin mass increases during pregnancy. Therefore, oxygen carrying capacity of blood also increases.(option D ruled out).
  • In pregnancy hemoglobin mass increases(to the extent of 18-20%) but hemoglobin concentration decreases due to hemodilution.
  • Iron metabolism in pregnancy.
    • During pregnancy there is marked demand for extra iron especially in the second half.
    • Even an adequate diet cannot provide the extra demand of iron.
    • Thus pregnancy is always a state of physiological iron deficiency.

questions.text: Most common cause of platelet ↓ in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gestational thrombocytopenia/Benign Gestational Thrombocytopenia

  • It is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia accounting for 80-90% of all cases of thrombocytopenia occurring during pregnancy.(Option A,C and D ruled out)
  • Exact cause is not known (may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption)
  • Platelet count is rarely <70,000/mm3.
  • Women are asymptomatic and there is no H/O bleeding.
  • The condition is benign and has no risk to mother or infant.
  • The only problem associated with it is - that anaesthesiologists are reluctant to give epidural or spinal anaesthesia if platelet count is < 1 lakh/mm3.
  • Treatment with steroids and IgG or platelet transfusion before delivery is sometimes necessary.

questions.text: Following hormones secreted by placenta exclusively:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The hormones produced by placenta exclusively therefore we cannot include - estrogen which is produced by placenta but not exclusively because the precursors for synthesis of estrogen are made available to the placenta by the fetal adrenal cortex, without which it cannot synthesise estrogen.
  • hCG and hPL are exclusively produced by the placenta.(Option A,B and C ruled out)

questions.text: Best test for estimating hCG:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Radioimmunoassay: This method uses a radioisotope as a label to detect and measure the amount of hormone in the sample. It is extremely sensitive, able to detect human chorionic gonadotropin levels up to 0.002 milli-international units per milliliter. Importantly, it is more specific than other tests because it does not cross-react with luteinizing hormone. For this reason, radioimmunoassay is considered the best test for detecting the beta subunit of human chorionic gonadotropin.
  • Bioassay: This was the earliest method developed in the 1930s. It involved injecting the patient's sample into animals such as rabbits or frogs and observing for ovulation. These tests were expensive, slow, and insensitive. They also could not differentiate between luteinizing hormone and human chorionic gonadotropin. Therefore, this test is now outdated.(Option D ruled out)
  • Enzyme linked immunosorbent assay: This test uses monoclonal antibodies that specifically bind to the beta subunit of human chorionic gonadotropin. It forms the basis of home pregnancy tests. It is highly sensitive and specific and can detect human chorionic gonadotropin in serum at levels as low as 1 to 2 milli-international units per milliliter.(Option B ruled out)
  • Radioreceptor assay (also called immunoradiometric assay): This method can detect human chorionic gonadotropin at levels up to 0.05 milli-international units per milliliter. Although it is sensitive, it is less specific compared to radioimmunoassay.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: In normal pregnancy character of vagina is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Changes in vagina during pregnancy:

  • Increase in the number of lactobacillus acidophilus (which act on glycogen and cause increased production of lactic acid therefore, pH becomes more acidic).
  • Increased vascularity and hyperemia (causes - violet colour characteristic of Chadwick sign).
  • Vaginal pH: decreases i.e. becomes acidic and varies from 3.5 to 6.
  • As pH of vagina becomes acidic - it inhibits the growth of pathogenic bacteria.(Option A and D ruled out)
  • Histopathology:
    • Early in pregnancy, the vaginal epithelial cells are similar to those seen in the luteal phase.
  • As pregnancy advances:
    • Small intermediate cells known as Navicular cells are seen in abundance in small clusters.
    • Vesicular nuclei without cytoplasm or so called Naked nuclei, are also seen along with abundant Lactobacillus.

questions.text: Hormone responsible for decidual reaction and Arias stella reaction in ectopic pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The hormone which is common to both Arias stella reaction and decidual reaction is progesterone.

Arias stella reaction

  • Arias stella reaction is characterized by adenomatous change of the endometrial glands.
  • Cells lose their polarity, have hyperchromatic nucleus, vacuolated cytoplasm and occasional mitosis.
  • The reaction is seen in ectopic pregnancy (in 10-15% cases) and indicates blightening of conceptus be it intrauterine or extrauterine. (therefore it is not specific for ectopic pregnancy)
  • It occurs under the influence of progesterone.

Decidual reaction:

  • Decidua is the specialized, highly modified endometrium of pregnancy formed by decidual reaction (decidualization), the estrogen- and progesterone-dependent conversion of secretory endometrium, which is completed only after blastocyst implantation.

questions.text: False regarding changes during pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In pregnancy, there is hyperplasia of the thyroid, parathyroid, pituitary, and adrenal cortex.(Option A, Option B ruled out)
  • Although the size of the thyroid gland increases, the patient remains euthyroid.
  • Basal metabolic rate increases (option D ruled out)
  • There is hyperinsulinemia during pregnancy (due to insulin resistance), to ensure continuous supply of glucose to the fetus.

Skin changes during pregnancy

  • During pregnancy, skin undergoes varying degrees of pigmentation, which varies among individuals. The dark line running centrally below the umbilicus is called the linea nigra.
  • Chloasma: It is hyperpigmentation of the skin around the cheeks, forehead, and eyes. The pigmentation is thought to be due to increased levels of endorphins and melanocyte stimulating hormone and disappears spontaneously after delivery.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida had prepregnancy BMI of 30 kg/m2. What is the recommended weight gain for her during pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Recommended Ranges of Total Gain for Pregnant Women by Prepregnancy Body Mass Index (BMI) for Singleton gestation is 5-7kg.(Option B,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Primigravida with full term, complains of faintness on lying down and she feels well when turned to side or sitting position. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Supine hypotension Syndrome (postural hypotension): During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava when the patient is in supine position.
  • In 90% cases this, however, results in opening up of the collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygos veins.
  • In some cases (10%), when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed.
  • This results in production of hypotension, tachycardia and syncope called supine hypotensive syndrome.
  • The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.
  • That is why pregnant females are advised to lie in lateral positions best being left lateral

questions.text: The following changes occur in urinary system in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Increased activity of ureters cannot be correct as the main hormone during pregnancy is progesterone which leads to relaxation of the smooth muscles of ureter. Therefore activity of ureters decreases and leads to urinary stasis.
  • During pregnancy Glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow increases (option a and b ruled out).
  • Anatomical changes in the renal system during pregnancy.
    • Both kidneys enlarge in pregnancy 1 cm.
    • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis occurs due to relaxant effect progesterone (These changes are M/c on right side).
    • Congestion of bladder leading to decreased bladder capacity.
    • To compensate, bladder pressure increases and intraurethral pressure increases.

questions.text: The role of human placental lactogen is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Human Placental Lactogen

  • Human chorionic somatotropin (hCS) is a polypeptide hormone secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast, structurally similar to pituitary growth hormone and prolactin, first detectable at 3 weeks post-fertilization (5 weeks gestational age) and rising progressively until 36 weeks.(Option A,B and C ruled out)

Role of HPL

  • HPL is mainly responsible for diabetogenic states in pregnancy. It antagonises the action of insulin.
  • Provides a source of energy for maternal metabolism and fetal nutrition.⇒ level of circulating Free Fatty Acid ↑ ⇒ It leads to maternal lipolysis
  • It is a potent angiogenic hormone therefore, may play important in fetal vasculature formation.
  • Levels of HPL are more in big babies and multiple pregnancies, making them all prone to develop gestational diabetes.
  • In free fatty acids and amino acids, it can indirectly lead to fetal growth. ↑As such HPL mainly plays role in maternal endocrine changes during pregnancy but due to those changes like
  • Because hPL is secreted primarily into maternal circulation with only small amounts in cord blood, it appears that its role in pregnancy, if any, is mediated through actions in maternal rather than in fetal tissues.

questions.text: The subcostal angle during pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During pregnancy, the enlarging uterus pushes the diaphragm upward and widens the lower thoracic cage.
  • As a result, the subcostal angle increases from about 68-70° in non-pregnant women to 105° at term.(Option A,B and D ruled out)
  • Anatomic changes in respiratory system:
    • Elevation of diaphragm by 4 cm
    • Transverse diameter of chest increases by 2 cm
    • Subcostal angle increases from 68-103°
    • Chest circumference increases by 5-7 cm

choices.text: Alteration of FHR on pressing the head into the pelvis
Spotting on the expected date of period in early months of pregnancy
Permanent lengthening of the cord in 3rd stage of labour
Slight gush of bleeding in third stage of labour

questions.text: The term 'placental sign' denotes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All pregnant females have amenorrhea. In a few pregnant females however, cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy, i.e. until the decidual space is obliterated by the fusion of decidua vera with decidua capsularis. Such bleeding is usually scanty, lasting for a shorter duration than her usual cycle and roughly corresponds with the date of the expected period. This is termed as placental sign or Hartman sign.
  • Relaxin is secreted by corpus luteum, decidua and placenta.

Explanation of other options:

  • Alteration of FHR on pressing the head into the pelvis(Option A): This is Pawlik's grip test (not placental sign).
  • Permanent lengthening of the cord in 3rd stage of labour (Option C): This is a sign of placental separation (not called placental sign).
  • Slight gush of bleeding in 3rd stage of labour(Option D): This is a sign of placental separation, but not the placental sign.
